docs.title: French Study Notes
docs.text: Welcome! This site is a collection of notes, vocabulary, and resources for learning French — specifically geared toward preparing for the TEF/TCF Canada exams.

docs.title: What's here
docs.text: • Word of the Day — Daily vocabulary with pronunciation guides and gender tips

docs.title: Quick reference
docs.text:
French English Pronunciation Bonjour Hello / Good day bohn-JOOR Merci Thank you mair-SEE S'il vous plaît Please (formal) seel voo PLEH Au revoir Goodbye oh ruh-VWAHR

Built with MkDocs Material.

docs.title: Week 1 Words
docs.text: Words and phrases learned during Week 1 (Feb 23 - Mar 1).

docs.title: The French Alphabet
docs.text: Letter French Name Sounds Like Watch Out A ah "ah" B bé "bay" C cé "say" D dé "day" E euh "uh" Not "ee" — sounds like "uh" F effe "eff" G gé "zhay" Not "jee" — soft "zh" sound H ache "ash" Always silent in French I ee "ee" J ji "zhee" Not "jay" — soft "zh" sound K ka "ka" L elle "L" M emme "em" N enne "en" O oh "oh" P pé "pay" Q ku "koo" R erre "air" Gargle from back of throat S esse "ess" T té "tay" U u "oo" lips, "ee" tongue Doesn't exist in English — practice! V vé "vay" W double vé "doo-bluh vay" X ixe "eeks" Y i grec "ee-GRECK" Means "Greek i" Z zède "zed"

docs.title: First Words
docs.text: Word Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Bonjour bohn-JOOR "bone-JOOR" Hello / good day Merci mair-SEE "mare-C" (letter C) Thank you Au revoir oh ruh-VWAHR "oh-ruh-VWOR" Goodbye

docs.title: Day 2 — Greetings
docs.text: Word Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Bonjour bohn-JOOR "bone-JOOR" Hello / good day Bonsoir bohn-SWAHR "bone-SWOR" Good evening Salut sa-LU "sa-LOO" Hi (informal) Comment allez-vous? koh-MAHN tah-lay VOO "co-MON ta-lay VOO" How are you? (formal) Ça va? sah VAH "sa VA" How's it going? (informal) Je m'appelle _____ zhuh mah-PEL "juh ma-PEL" My name is _____ Merci beaucoup mair-SEE boh-KOO "mare-C bo-COO" Thank you very much S'il vous plaît seel voo PLEH "seal voo PLAY" (almost) Please Au revoir oh ruh-VWAHR "oh-ruh-VWOR" Goodbye Excusez-moi ex-ku-ZAY mwah "ex-coo-ZAY mwa" Excuse me

docs.title: Day 3 — Subject Pronouns + Être
docs.text:
Subject Pronouns:

Word Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Je zhuh "juh" I Tu tu "too" You (informal) Il eel "eel" He Elle el "L" (letter L) She On ohn "own" (nasal) We (informal) / one Nous noo "new" We (formal) Vous voo "voo" You (formal or plural) Ils eel "eel" They (masc. or mixed) Elles el "L" (letter L) They (all female)

Être (to be):

French Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Je suis zhuh SWEE "juh SWEE" I am Tu es tu EH "too EH" You are Il/elle est eel/el EH "eel EH" He/she is Nous sommes noo SUM "new SUM" We are Vous êtes voo ZET "voo ZET" You are Ils/elles sont eel/el SOHN "eel SEWN" (nasal) They are

docs.title: Day 4 — Avoir (to have)
docs.text: French Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning J'ai zhay "JAY" (letter J) I have Tu as tu AH "too AH" You have Il/elle a eel/el AH "eel AH" He/she has Nous avons noo za-VOHN "new za-VON" (like Avon) We have Vous avez voo za-VAY "voo za-VAY" You have Ils/elles ont eel/el ZOHN "eel ZONE" (nasal) They have

docs.title: Day 5 — Articles
docs.text:
Definite articles (= "the"):

Article Sounds Like Use with Example Le "luh" masculine singular le livre (the book) La "la" (like singing) feminine singular la maison (the house) L' "l" before vowel/silent h l'homme (the man) Les "LAY" all plurals les livres (the books)

docs.title: Day 6 — Indefinite Articles + Negation
docs.text:
Indefinite articles (= "a/an/some"):

Article Sounds Like Use with Example Un "uh" + nasal masculine singular un livre (a book) Une "oon" feminine singular une maison (a house) Des "DAY" all plurals des livres (some books)

Negation keywords:

Word Sounds Like Meaning Ne...pas "nuh...PAH" not (wraps around the verb)

docs.title: Day 7 — Review
docs.text:
No new words — review all of the above!

Week 1 total

By end of Week 1 you should recognize ~100 common French words including all pronouns, être/avoir conjugations, articles, and basic greetings.

docs.title: Week 1: French Sounds & First Words
docs.text: Goal: Learn French sounds, master être/avoir, build your first 100 words.

docs.title: Day 1 — Setup & The Alphabet
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Watch: French Alphabet Pronunciation — listen and repeat each letter
  • Pay attention to: E ("uh"), G ("zhay"), J ("zhee"), R (back of throat), U (lips say "oo", tongue says "ee")

Evening (~30 min)

  • [ ] Watch: French greetings for beginners — pick any short video
  • [ ] Practice saying 3x each: Bonjour (bone-JOOR), Merci (mare-C), Au revoir (oh-ruh-VWOR)

Before bed

  • [ ] Say all three greetings out loud one more time

docs.title: Day 2 — Greetings
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Review the Day 2 word list — read each word and say it out loud 3x

Evening (~30 min)

  • [ ] Watch: French greetings — Comme Une Française
  • [ ] Practice introducing yourself out loud: "Bonjour, je m'appelle _____. Comment allez-vous?"
  • [ ] Go through the Day 2 words again — cover the "Meaning" column and test yourself

docs.title: Day 3 — Subject Pronouns + Être (to be)
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Review the subject pronouns table — say each one 3x

Evening (~30 min)

  • [ ] Study the être conjugation — write it out on paper, say each form 3x
  • [ ] Practice these sentences out loud:
    • "Je suis _" (I am ___)
    • "Il est grand" (He is tall)
    • "Elle est intelligente" (She is smart)
    • "Nous sommes contents" (We are happy)

Before bed

  • [ ] Try to say all 6 être forms from memory (je suis, tu es, il est...)

docs.title: Day 4 — Avoir (to have)
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Review avoir conjugation — say each form 3x

Evening (~30 min)

  • [ ] Write 5 sentences mixing être and avoir. Templates:
    1. "Je suis _ et j'ai _ ans." (I am _ and I am ___ years old.)
    2. "Elle est gentille et elle a un chat." (She is kind and she has a cat.)
    3. "Nous sommes contents." (We are happy.)
    4. "Ils ont une maison." (They have a house.)
    5. "Tu es intelligent et tu as un livre." (You are smart and you have a book.)

Before bed

  • [ ] From memory: conjugate être then avoir out loud

docs.title: Day 5 — Articles + First Podcast
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Review definite articles (le, la, l', les)

Evening (~30 min)

  • [ ] Listen: Coffee Break French Season 1 Episode 1 — just listen, don't stress about understanding everything
  • [ ] Study the gender rules: -tion, -ée, -ance = feminine / -age, -ment, -eau = masculine

Before bed

  • [ ] Point at 5 objects around you and say "le" or "la" + the French word (use Google Translate to look them up)

docs.title: Day 6 — Indefinite Articles + Negation
docs.text:
Morning (~15 min)

  • [ ] Review indefinite articles & negation (un, une, des + ne...pas)

Evening (~45 min)

  • [ ] Watch: French negation — Comme Une Française
  • [ ] Watch: Être & Avoir conjugation
  • [ ] Write 6 negative sentences:
    1. Je ne suis pas américain. (I am not American.)
    2. Elle n'a pas de chien. (She doesn't have a dog.)
    3. Nous ne sommes pas fatigués. (We are not tired.)
    4. Il n'est pas grand. (He is not tall.)
    5. Tu n'as pas de voiture. (You don't have a car.)
    6. Make up your own!
  • [ ] Read all 6 sentences out loud slowly

docs.title: Day 7 — Review Day
docs.text:
Morning (~30 min)

  • [ ] Without looking, write out on paper:
    • All 9 subject pronouns
    • Full être conjugation
    • Full avoir conjugation
    • The articles (le, la, l', les, un, une, des)
    • Negation rule (ne + verb + pas)
  • [ ] Check your answers against the Week 1 Words page

Afternoon (~30 min)

  • [ ] Write 10 sentences using everything from this week (use the templates from the week)
  • [ ] Watch any French beginner video on YouTube that looks fun — just for immersion

Before bed

  • [ ] Say from memory: "Bonjour, je m'appelle _. J'ai ___ ans. Je ne suis pas français. Merci, au revoir!"

docs.title: Week 1 Checklist
docs.text:
By end of Day 7, you should be able to:

  • [ ] Recognize French letter sounds
  • [ ] Greet someone (bonjour, bonsoir, salut, comment allez-vous)
  • [ ] Introduce yourself (je m'appelle..., j'ai ... ans)
  • [ ] Conjugate être without looking
  • [ ] Conjugate avoir without looking
  • [ ] Know when to use le/la/l'/les and un/une/des
  • [ ] Make a sentence negative with ne...pas

docs.title: All Words
docs.text: Master list of every French word and phrase accumulated across all weeks.

docs.title: Essential Words
docs.text: Word Pronunciation Sounds Like Gender Quick Tip Bon bohn "bone" (without the e) Masculine Used before masculine nouns Bonne bun "ban" Feminine Used before feminine nouns Nuit nwee "nwee" like "wee!" with an N Feminine The "t" is silent Appétit ah-peh-TEE "a-peh-T" (letter T) Masculine Stress the last syllable Voyage vwah-YAHJ "vwah-yoj" Masculine Soft "j" sound at the end Journée joor-NAY "joor-NAY" like "nay!" Feminine "Day" (as in "have a good day") Chance shahnss "shonce" Feminine Sounds nothing like English "chance"

docs.title: Common Phrases
docs.text: Phrase Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Bonjour bohn-JOOR "bone-JOOR" Hello / good day Bonsoir bohn-SWAHR "bone-SWOR" Good evening Bonne nuit bun nwee "ban wee" Good night (said at bedtime) Merci mair-SEE "mare-C" (letter C) Thank you S'il vous plaît seel voo PLEH "seal voo PLAY" (almost) Please (formal) Oui wee "wee" Yes Non nohn "no" + hum through nose No Au revoir oh ruh-VWAHR "oh-ruh-VWOR" Goodbye

docs.title: Week 1 Words
docs.text: Word Pronunciation Sounds Like Meaning Je zhuh "juh" I Tu tu "too" You (informal) Il eel "eel" He Elle el "L" (letter L) She On ohn "own" (nasal) We (informal) / one Nous noo "new" We (formal) Vous voo "voo" You (formal or plural) Ils eel "eel" They (masc.) Elles el "L" (letter L) They (fem.) Suis swee "swee" Am (je suis = I am) Est eh "eh" Is Sommes sum "sum" Are (nous sommes) Êtes et "et" Are (vous êtes) Sont sohn "sewn" (nasal) Are (ils/elles sont) Ai ay "A" (letter A) Have (j'ai = I have) As ah "ah" Have (tu as) Avons ah-vohn "a-VON" (like the company) Have (nous avons) Avez ah-vay "a-VAY" like "hooray" Have (vous avez) Ont ohn "own" (nasal) Have (ils/elles ont) Le luh "luh" The (masculine) La lah "la" like singing "la la la" The (feminine) Les lay "LAY" The (plural) Un uhn "uh" + nasal A (masculine) Une oon "oon" A (feminine) Des day "DAY" Some (plural)

docs.title: Gender Tips
docs.text:
How to guess gender

There's no perfect rule, but these patterns help:

Feminine — words ending in: -tion, -ée, -ance, -ence, -ure, -nuit

Masculine — words ending in: -age, -ment, -it, -eau, -isme

docs.title: Pronunciation Notes
docs.text:
The French \"u\" sound

The French u (as in nuit) doesn't exist in English. Round your lips like you're saying "oo" but try to say "ee" instead. Practice with: tu, rue, nuit, lune.

Nasal vowels

French has nasal vowels where air goes through the nose. In bon (bohn), the "n" isn't fully pronounced — it nasalizes the vowel. Same with non (nohn).
